utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, I read that someone invented a way to convert your footsteps into electromagnetic energy so you can charge your cell phone while walking.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We had that idea years ago. How come we never did anything with it?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Probably because we left the diagram of it in the restaurant, and none of us wanted to walk back.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I know the real reason you never made progress with that idea. You thought of it September 22nd, 2007. Two days later, Penny moved in, and so much blood rushed to your genitals, your brain became a ghost town.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’s not what happened.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I remember it distinctly because I had just composed my annual poem commemorating the anniversary of Dr. Seuss’s death.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No one wants to hear it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why, die. Why did he die? Old, told. I was told he was old.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Penny is not the reason I didn’t pursue that idea.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, really? Since meeting her, what have been your greatest accomplishments?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Easy. Sleeping with Penny.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Getting Penny to go back out with him after she dumped him.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Tricking Penny into getting engaged.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: And a few weeks ago, he almost did a pull-up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I think someone owes me an apology.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, don’t feel bad. I think we’ve all been distracted since the girls entered our lives.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You admit Amy’s a distraction?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, very much so. Listen to this. This is from two days ago. Hi. Hope you’re having a good day. Who has time for this constant sexting?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, maybe we have lost our focus.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It wouldn’t kill us to get together and brainstorm ideas.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ooh, we could have one of those retreats.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: My cousin has a cabin out in the woods.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m not going to a cabin in the woods. Did you see the movie Cabin in the Woods?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Then we’ll go to a hotel.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A hotel? Did you see The Shining?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: We could go up to Big Bear and get a house on the lake.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Did you see The Lake House?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Nothing bad happens in The Lake House.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, well, no, not to them. To me. Time traveling mailbox. The only time that traveled was an hour and half of my life down the toilet.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Fine. Then we’ll just stay here and do it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, you didn’t suggest a beach house.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You would go to a beach house?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, good Lord, no, have you seen Jaws?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey. So, the guys and I are talking about having kind of a science retreat this weekend. I just wanted to know if that’s okay. You and I had talked about going to brunch on Sunday.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Want to go to Vegas this weekend?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Of course I do.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Bernadette? Girl’s weekend. Vegas. You in?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Hell, yeah.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes. I’ll check flights.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I’ll check hotels.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’ll check my underpants. I’m so excited, I think I peed.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: They seem okay with it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey. I didn’t think you’d make it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, ’cause you have a steady girlfriend now, and we assumed you’d have to stay home to lower the food down to her in the pit.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: For your information, Emily is working tonight.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, one would assume, on getting out of the pit.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, let’s focus. The girls are gone, we have 48 hours. There are no distractions. Let’s change the world.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thinking caps on.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Here we go.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ooh, this is exciting. We’re innovating. I feel like we’re in the Facebook movie.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh. I never saw that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh. It’s wonderful, and I swear I’m not saying that because Justin Timberlake is in it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, I have it on Blu-ray. We should watch it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Cool. I’ll make the popcorn.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Guys, in 30 seconds, we went from let’s change the world to let’s watch TV.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry. Is that a no?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay. No. Leonard’s right. We’re here to focus. Didn’t we used to have a list of all our ideas?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I, I think I still have it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I did not get a clear answer. I’m gonna set this down now.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Ah, here it is. Whoa. I haven’t looked at these in years. Robot girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Mm, that was mine.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Robot prostitute.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Also mine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wait. I’m confused. Why would you need both a robot girlfriend and a robot prostitute?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: There’s just some things you don’t do with your robot girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Boy, when you met Bernadette, the field of robotics really took a hit.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, let’s just skip all the inventions you can have sex with. All right, no, here we go, ergonomic heated seat cushion.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, it vibrates. Keep going.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know, let’s just come up with something new.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know, a number of significant innovations have been inspired by science fiction. The, the geosynchronous satellite from Arthur C. Clarke. The Motorola flip phone, that came from Star Trek. And I’ve long suspected that the idea of an African-American president was stolen from the movie Deep Impact.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, the future they show in Back to the Future II is only a year away. A lot of the things in that movie haven’t been invented yet.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How cool would that be if we could make one of those a reality?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If we could figure out the scientific basis for Marty’s hover board, that would have universal application.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, it’s, it’s possible at absolute zero, but we would have to remove the temperature restrictions.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, I have an idea.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I think I have the same one.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We got to watch Back to the Future II.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’ll make the popcorn.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, where should we go first?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Ooh. There’s a cover band in the lounge.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Nah.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: But they play Barry Manilow.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: But they’re called Fairly Manilow.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh. Okay.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Great.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, what do you want to do?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, we’re in Vegas. I want to go downstairs, get a bucket of margaritas, dance until I vomit all over a roulette wheel and watch it go everywhere.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: What if we don’t want to vomit?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, you will. That’s why they give you the bucket. Uh-oh.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It’s my boss. They moved my field ride up to Monday.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: What does that mean?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It means instead of having a week to study, I only have two days.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: That sucks.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Can you start in the morning?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, it’s kind of a lot. You know, let me do a little tonight, and I’ll catch up with you guys later.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You sure?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, it’s okay. Go ahead.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: So, um, now that Penny’s not coming…

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: We’re not seeing Fairly Manilow.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hold on. Pause. Something doesn’t make sense. Look, in 2015, Biff steals the sports almanac and takes the time machine back to 1955, to give it to his younger self. But as soon as he does that, he changes the future, so the 2015 he returns to would be a different 2015, not the 2015 that Marty and Doc were in.

utterance.speaker: Leoanard
utterance.content: This is Hot Tub Time Machine all over again. If future Biff goes back to 2015 right after he gives young Biff the almanac, he could get back to the 2015 with Marty and Doc in it. Because it wasn’t until his 21st birthday that 1955 Biff placed his first bet.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wait. Whoa, whoa. Is placed right?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What do you mean?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is placed the right tense for something that would have happened in the future of a past that was affected by something from the future?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Had will have placed?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s my boy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, so, it wasn’t until his 21st birthday that Biff had will have placed his first bet and made his millions. That’s when he altered the timeline.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, but he had will haven’t placed it!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Unlike Hot Tub Time Machine, this couldn’t be more simple. When Biff gets the almanac in 1955, the alternate future he creates isn’t the one in which Marty and Doc Brown ever use the time machine to travel to 2015. Therefore, in the new timeline, Marty and Doc never brought the time machine…

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Wait. Is brought right?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Marty and Doc never had have had brought?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know. You did it to me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I’m going with it. Marty and Doc never had have had brought the time machine to 2015. That means 2015 Biff could also not had have had brought the almanac to 1955 Biff. Therefore, the timeline in which 1955 Biff gets the almanac is also the timeline in which 1955 Biff never gets the almanac. And not just never gets. Never have, never hasn’t, never had have hasn’t.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: He’s right. Also, what kind of name is Biff? Sounds like when you pop open a can of Pillsbury dough. Biff.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, that stuff is so good wrapped around cocktail weenies.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Guys.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Do you know that the word wiener comes from the German name of the Austrian capital Vienna, or Wien?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Do you know if you look at Austria on a map it actually looks like a wiener?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Guys, what are we doing? We sent the girls away so we could focus.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t think it worked.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Maybe after this, you’ll be in the mood for some Manilow.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I think after this, I’ll be dead.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Look at us out, while Penny’s in the room studying.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I’m proud of her. This is a great opportunity. It’s nice to see her take it seriously.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: It is. But enough about Penny. Let’s talk about us. We’re looking good.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: We are.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Better than good. I mean, look at you. Your body’s bangin’.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Amy.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Don’t Amy me. We’re always talking about how hot Penny is. Come on, scientist to scientist, how big are those Hadron Colliders?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You’re embarrassing me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh, don’t be embarrassed. I’ll show you the divot in my spine.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: No, no, it’s okay. I was born with it. If you put a double-A battery in there, it makes my leg kick.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: All right.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, this is already better. There are far fewer distractions in here.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Plus, this is where our minds are conditioned to focus on work.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, I’ve been thinking about the hover boards, and maybe there’s a way we could use Maglev technology.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Or if we could figure out a way to supercool the materials, we could utilize quantum coupling.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I wonder if anyone’s tried that.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Go online and look it up.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, I can’t argue with him. It’s right there on the screen. Austria does look like a wiener.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: That’s nothing, dude. Go check out how hung Florida is.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m sure Mrs. Florida’s walking funny. Can we get back to work?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, he’s right. Oh, here’s a thought. What if we use some form of operant conditioning techniques to keep us from getting off topic?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Like behavior modification?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, exactly. Did you know those techniques were used to actually teach pigeons to play ping-pong?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: That cannot be true.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, it was match point.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Some psychologists perform operant conditioning with punishment. Maybe we can come up with a punishment for straying off topic.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Not getting to see who wins at pigeon ping-pong comes to mind.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We could snap a rubber band on our wrists every time we get sidetracked.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Mmm, not bad. You know, in medieval times, idle chatter was punished with a device called the scold’s bridle. It’s an iron cage that’s locked around the head and pierces the tongue.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If only we had one.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I’ll check Amazon.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Housekeeping.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: We had a complaint about somebody pooping on a party in there.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: It was us the whole time.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Why’d you tell her? It was working.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Was it working?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, I’m so sorry.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You guys look like you’re having fun.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: We’re having the best time.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Guess who won a hundred dollars playing craps.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: That’s a dollar.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Then guess who wildly overtipped a cocktail waitress.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hey, Penny, hey, let’s go. We found a place that has Australian male strippers.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: We want to see if they twirl their junk in the other direction.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: That sounds so great. But I have a little more studying to do.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Can you believe this nerd?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Come on, do you want to sit here being a loser, or do you want to watch me climb into an Australian man’s G-string like a baby kangaroo?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: All right, guys, look, I would love to go out, but I’ve got to get this done, okay? So have fun at the club. And if you get in trouble, find a policeman. And if he’s taking off his pants, he is not a real policeman.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Okay, okay, this is obviously very important to her. Let’s just, we’ll help her study so she can get done quicker. Here, here, I’m gonna quiz you. I’m gonna quiz you. I got your notes. I got your notes. I got your notes. If you want these, they’re gonna be at the strip club.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Aren’t you gonna chase her?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: To the walk-in closet? Sure.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, so we agree, whenever someone takes us off topic they get their arm hair yanked off.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: And I really can’t let that happen or the girl who does my eyebrows will think I’ve been cheating on her.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: All right, now, one benefit of quantum coupling…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wait, a question, who decides if someone’s gone off topic?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I think it’ll be pretty clear. If not, we’ll take a vote. Oh, and also…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ow. We didn’t vote!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We didn’t have to, that was clearly a tangent. Now come on. Back to work. If we’re leaning towards quantum coupling… Aah! Why?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You said quantum coupling. That made me think of the show Quantum Leap. That’s a tangent and it’s your fault.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s ridiculous. Sheldon, I vote that is not a tangent.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you. And now I owe you one.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ow. That was your fault.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ooh, that is a lot of hair. Ow. And now I’m gonna hear it from Jenny.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Everyone stop. This was a stupid idea. Negative reinforcement isn’t working.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I think you mean positive punishment. Negative reinforcement is the removal of a positive stimulus. It’s a common mistake.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Negative reinforcement is really wrong?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, it’s used incorrectly all the time. Even Bill Murray makes that mistake in the first scene of Ghostbusters.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No way. Not Bill Murray.

utterance.speaker: Bill Murray (on screen)
utterance.content: I’m studying the effect of negative reinforcement on ESP ability.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Huh. Bill Murray did get it wrong.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Jump ahead to the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard’s right. We can’t just jump ahead. We have to watch the whole movie.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Look. We keep procrastinating. We saw Back to the Future II, pigeons playing ping-pong, a bunch of countries that look like genitals and one guy whose genitals look like Denmark.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, sorry for clicking on that.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s late. We’ve wasted hours. Can we please find it in ourselves to do any amount of work tonight?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But we didn’t see them bust one ghost.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So you’re, you’re saying we should stand here in my lab on a Saturday night and watch the rest of Ghostbusters on a crappy laptop?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: All
utterance.content: Ghostbusters!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It really does hold up.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: See? Isn’t this better than a hotel room?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yep. Shake that thing.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Have you ever seen a body so fine?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: We had some pretty hot corpses in my anatomy class, but none of them moved like that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Good morning. You want to go to the pool? Come on, you said it yourself, only nerds and losers stay in the room. Wow, it’s bright out. Isn’t it bright? I should probably close these curtains. Nah. Bye.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Would you please close the drapes?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Okay.
